channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: India Ink: Hopes of Electoral Change Bring Foreigners Back to Indian Markets
item.description: Indian stock markets have been hitting record highs as investors anticipate that a business-friendly leader will become the next prime minister, but analysts caution that the outcome of the national elections is far from certain.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By NEHA THIRANI BAGRI

item.title: India Ink: Aam Aadmi Party Leader Declares Candidacy in Varanasi
item.description: Arvind Kejriwal, the former chief minister of Delhi, will face Narendra Modi of the Bharatiya Janata Party, turning the ancient city into one of the most hotly contested battlegrounds for the parliamentary elections.
item.dc:creator: By BETWA SHARMA
item.media:description: Arvind Kejriwal, leader of the Aam Aadmi Party, after he arrived in Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh, for an election campaign.

item.title: Secret Service Pulls Agents From Detail for Drinking
item.description: The revelation is the latest embarrassment for the agency whose agents’ behavior has been under scrutiny since April 2012 when several were caught with prostitutes in their hotel rooms.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT

item.title: North Korea Launches Two Midrange Missiles
item.description: The move came after the leaders of the United States, Japan and South Korea gathered in the Netherlands to discuss the North’s nuclear threats.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: White House Protests Saudi’s Denial of Visa to Journalist
item.description: Saudi Arabia denied a visa to a Washington-based reporter for The Jerusalem Post who had planned to cover President Obama’s trip to the Arab kingdom this week.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER

item.title: World Briefing: Turkey: Compensation Deal Near in 2010 Israeli Raid
item.description: The Turkish deputy premier said Tuesday that Turkey could soon reach an agreement with Israel on compensation for the victims of a 2010 Israeli raid, a key condition for restoring ties.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Denmark: Copenhagen Zoo Kills Four Lions
item.description: The zoo that faced protests for the killing last month of a healthy giraffe to prevent inbreeding said Tuesday that it had killed four lions, including two cubs, to make room for a new male lion.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Obama Meets With Asian Allies on North Korea’s Nuclear Plans
item.description: President Obama brought together the sometimes-squabbling leaders of Japan and South Korea on Tuesday for a discussion in advance of his visit to both countries next month.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR

item.title: DealBook: Candy Crush Maker King Digital Set to Trade at $22.50
item.description: European technology entrepreneurs and investors say a successful initial public offering by King Digital would validate Europe’s reputation as a global center for start-ups and innovation.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL J. DE LA MERCED and MARK SCOTT
item.media:description: Candy Crush Saga has been a big hit for King Digital, which begins trading on Wednesday.

item.title: Qaeda Militants Seek Syria Base, U.S. Officials Say
item.description: Intelligence assessments say that Al Qaeda’s leadership is developing a long-term plan to create cells in Syria to train Westerners to carry out plots against targets in the West.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Islamic State of Iraq and Syria
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: Fighters from Al Qaeda’s main affiliate in Syria, the Nusra Front, last April near Aleppo.

item.title: U.S. Challenge Now Is to Stop Further Putin Moves
item.description: Officials in the United States and Europe have privately concluded that Crimea is lost and that the real challenge is stopping Russia from further destabilizing Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER and MICHAEL D. SHEAR
item.media:description: Barricades still surround Independence Square, known as Maidan, in Kiev, Ukraine’s capital.

item.title: Obama Says N.S.A. Curbs Would Address Worries
item.description: The president said the new procedures for the use of phone records would help preserve privacy while keeping the program’s usefulness in fighting terrorism.
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: Obama Answers Critics, Dismissing Russia as a ‘Regional Power’
item.description: In language that seemed to be aimed at the highest ranks inside the Kremlin, President Obama dismissed Russia as a country that is lashing out at its neighbors “not out of strength, but out of weakness.”
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR and PETER BAKER
item.media:description: President Obama with Ban Ki-moon, the United Nations secretary general, and other world leaders and officials in The Hague on Tuesday.

item.title: Caracas Journal: Protesting in Venezuela, With Antipathy Toward Cuba’s Government
item.description: Many Venezuelan protesters have also focused their resentment on Cuba’s government, which, they say, has leeched off Venezuela’s oil wealth and grafted its rigid brand of socialism onto their country.
item.dc:creator: By VICTORIA BURNETT and WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: At a protest this month in Caracas, Venezuela, doctors’ signs spoke to a Cuban presence in their field.

item.title: On Visit to China, Michelle Obama Eases In Some Political Messages
item.description: What seemed to start as a spring break holiday for the first lady has turned out to be far more substantive than what the cheerful advocate of fitness and healthful eating often displays at home.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ and MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: Michelle Obama, practicing tai chi with students in Chengdu, has spoken openly about free expression and minority rights.

item.title: Pollution Killed 7 Million People Worldwide in 2012, Report Finds
item.description: A World Health Organization report concluded that more than one-third of pollution deaths in 2012 occurred in fast-developing Asian nations.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS and IAN JOHNSON
item.media:description: A tourist boat navigated through a haze in the Guangdong Province of China this month. The country’s rapid urbanization was cited as contributing to pollution.

item.title: Search for Missing Flight’s Wreckage Is Hampered by a Sea of Detritus
item.description: Marine debris experts said that objects spotted in the search area for the Malaysia Airlines jetliner could be just about anything, from mattresses to shipping containers.
item.dc:creator: By HENRY FOUNTAIN

item.title: Terror Case Against Aide to Bin Laden Goes to Jury
item.description: The jury is weighing terrorism charges against Sulaiman Abu Ghaith, who was a top adviser to Osama bin Laden.
item.dc:creator: By BENJAMIN WEISER

item.title: Prosecution Rests Case in Pistorius Murder Trial
item.description: During three weeks of testimony, the prosecution sought to portray Oscar Pistorius, the Paralympic athlete, as an angry and jealous man who had killed his girlfriend, but he has maintained that the shooting was a horrible accident.
item.dc:creator: By SARAH LYALL

item.title: Square Feet: Macau Rides High on New Round of Casino Construction
item.description: A construction boom in the Asian gambling hub epitomizes the rising spending power of Chinese consumers.
item.dc:creator: By BETTINA WASSENER

item.title: Vast Web Hides Mexican Drug Profits in Plain Sight, U.S. Authorities Say
item.description: Many of those suspected of forming Mexico’s largest drug cartel’s network still operate, even though they appear, as Hugo Cuéllar Hurtado did, on the United States’ list of operatives.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD

item.title: Senate Democrats Drop I.M.F. Reforms From Ukraine Aid
item.description: The move to drop overhauls of International Monetary Fund governance from a Ukraine aid package handed President Obama an embarrassing defeat.
item.dc:creator: By JONATHAN WEISMAN
item.media:description: Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the Senate majority leader, spoke to reporters on Capitol Hill on Tuesday.

item.title: Judge in Mumbai Rape Case Calls Test on Women Archaic
item.description: The judge complained about the treatment of rape victims, calling a test to determine whether a woman’s hymen has been freshly broken “degrading, unscientific and archaic.”
item.dc:creator: By MANSI CHOKSI and ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Tests Rule Out Ebola in Canadian Patient
item.description: Reports of the illness in a man who had recently visited West Africa had led to speculation that the virus had appeared for the first time in Canada.
item.dc:creator: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: DealBook: British Government to Sell a Big Stake in Lloyds Banking
item.description: In a sign that Britain’s financial sector is strengthening, the sale of shares will reduce the government’s stake in Lloyds to about 25 percent from about 32.7 percent.
item.dc:creator: By CHAD BRAY
item.media:description: A branch of Lloyds Bank in London.
